At present, glacier velocity estimation relies on sparse cross-correlation estimates and computationally expensive optical flow solutions. We present a novel use of deep learning for estimating annual glacier velocities, utilizing the recurrent optical-flow based architecture, RAFT, on consecutive pairs of optical Sentinel-2 imagery. Our results demonstrate that deep learning can generate dense per-pixel velocity estimates within an automated framework that utilizes Sentinel-2 images over the French Alps.

The evolution of glaciers is widely regarded as a significant indicator of climate change. These systems play a crucial role in global mean sea level rise, contributing up to 25-30% over past decades. This, in addition to the increased frequency of natural hazards affecting mountainous communities and evolving local hydrology, motivates the need for improved glacier monitoring. Advancements in spaceborne remote sensing capabilities have led to enhanced data availability with higher spatial resolution and lower revisit times. Glacier surface displacements can be inferred from successive optical or radar remote sensing images through feature tracking algorithms based on cross-correlation and optical flow techniques.

A range of toolboxes have been developed with end-to-end workflows for feature tracking, utilizing these classical algorithms. Efforts have been made to produce databases mapping glacier surface velocities at regional and global scales from archives of Sentinel-2 and Landsat imagery. Recently, deep learning computer vision algorithms have been effective at learning velocity fields from series of images, producing state-of-the-art optical flow estimation across synthetic datasets and fluid flow estimation problems. Deep learning for glacier monitoring has been applied to the mapping of glacier extents, glacier debris classification, and mapping glacial lakes from remote sensing images. However, the efficacy of deep learning optical flow methods for inferring glacier velocity fields remains to be fully investigated.

We present a novel use of deep learning for mapping glacier-scale velocity fields from remote sensing imagery. We adopt a Recurrent All-Pairs Field Transforms (RAFT) based architecture to estimate dense optical flow velocity fields from Sentinel-2 imagery. Our study site is the Mer de Glace of the Mont Blanc massif in the French Alps, occupying an area of approximately 30 km^2.

Our methodology involves processing Sentinel-2 images for input to the RAFT model and generating target velocity fields for supervised learning. The employed data processing pipeline is similar to the automated framework proposed by Millan et al. for generating glacier velocities from multiple spaceborne imaging platforms. We download Sentinel-2 images over the region of interest in Google Earth Engine, filtering by cloud cover and avoiding winter months with snowfall and homogeneous surface texture. We use the near-infrared band (Sentinel-2 band 8) for analysis, as it produces sufficient radiometric response. The downloaded images are then Sobel-filtered to enhance contrast and mitigate against shadows caused by complex topography in mountainous regions. We use glacier outlines from the Randolf Glacier Inventory to generate image masks and remove non-glacierized regions ahead of velocity estimation. The processed images are then combined into image pairs and segmented into overlapping tiles of size 256x256, which is the input size of the RAFT model. Data augmentation is performed using rotations to modify the dataset size and improve robustness. Training labels are generated from a classical multi-level Horn-Schunk solution implemented in Matlab, producing dense per-pixel velocity fields for the image pairs. The resulting velocity fields are filtered for outliers using a 9x9 median filter.
